Non-halogen ionic liquids are considered efficient catalyst for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates. In this work, six carboxylic acid ionic liquids with different types and sizes of cations are designed and synthesized to systematically investigate the catalytic contribution of the non-halogen cation and anion for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonate. The result shows that the anion could improve the catalytic activity by improve the basicity of ionic liquids, and the cation that has a weak interaction with anion is more conducive for the reactivity. Further, the reaction mechanism is deeply studied by using the optimized [P4444][IsoNic]: two reaction intermediates are captured by In-situ infrared, combined with DFT calculation, the anion directly inducing ring-opening mechanism is proposed. This work provides an in-depth understanding of catalytic contribution of non-halogen ionic liquids used in cycloaddition reaction. Graphical Abstract Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Non-halogen ionic liquids CO2 conversion Cyclic carbonate, Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a main greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide has attracted wide attention. Using carbon dioxide as a cheap and safe C1 resource [1]to synthesize fine chemicals benefits carbon capture and utilization, which is an effective way to achieve carbon neutrality [2]. Therein, the atom economic route that incorporation of CO2 into epoxides (Scheme 1 ) is particularly attractive because of its widely used product cyclic carbonate, which is often used as an aprotic solvent and electrolyte of lithium batteries for its excellent properties such as low toxicity, high boiling point, and biodegradability [3]. To date, various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been utilized for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, such as metal oxides [4], alkali metal salts [5,6], ionic liquids [7–12], transition metal complexes [13–15]and organic bases [16,17] ect. Among them, Ionic liquids are considered as ideal catalysts of the cycloaddition reaction for their excellent activity and high thermal stability. However, halogens are usually taken as anions (F−/Br−/I−) when the ionic liquids are applied as catalysts, which are corrosive and environmentally unfriendly. Based on the existing problems, the development of non-halogen ionic liquid catalysts for coupling CO2 and epoxides has attracted extensive attention from industry and academia. The main anions used in the non-halogen ionic liquids are peroxic metals [18,19], azoles [20], and carboxylic acids [21–23]. Among them, the carboxylic anions are easily prepared and highly active. For cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by non-halogen ionic liquids, as the key active substance, many studies improved the catalytic activity by regulating anion [20,24,25]. In 2022, in the reaction of CO2 and 2-aminobenzonitrile to quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-diones, Tengfei Wang [26] found that the strong interaction between cation and anion would result in a decreased yield. It inspired us to consider the effect of cation on catalytic activity in addition to the anion. In this work, we designed and synthesized six carboxylic acid ionic liquids with different types and sizes of cations. The effect of cation and anion on catalytic activity was deeply studied. After ionic liquids screening, the optimal ionic liquid was selected to thoroughly investigate the catalytic mechanism by in-situ infrared and DFT calculations. This work reveals the catalytic contribution of non-halogen cation and anion in cycloaddition reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Tetrabutylphosphonium bromide (98 %), 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‑7-ene (99 %), and Styrene oxide (98 %) was received from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Trihexyl(tetradecyl)phosphonium bromide (≥95 %) was from Sigma-Aldrich Trading Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China) while anion exchange resin Ambersep 900(OH) was supplied from Alfa Aesar. All other chemical compounds including 1-Butyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium chloride (97 %), Isonicotinic acid (99 %), 2-Picolinic acid (99 %), Propylene oxide (>99 %) and 1,2-Butylene Oxide (>99 %), etc. were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All reagents were directly used without further purified. Carbon dioxide was supplied from Beijing Analytical Instrument Factory with a purity of 99.99 %. 2.2 Characterization methods 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded in D2O or [D6]DMSO on a Bruker AVANCE III HD 600 NMR spectrometer, and the chemical shifts were shown in units of parts per million relatives to TMS. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected on a Thermo Nicolet 380 spectrophotometer using anhydrous KBr as background. Mass analyses of catalysts were performed on an Agilent QTOF-6550 mass spectrometer with an electrospray ionization source. In addition, decomposition temperatures of ionic liquids were operated on a TG-DTA6300 simultaneous thermogravimetric analyzer under the N2 atmosphere in the temperature range from room temperature to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Epoxides conversion and product selectivity were quantified by 1H NMR spectroscopy, with N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) as internal standard. Finally, the reaction process was monitored at 50 °C by a diffuse in-situ infrared analyzer with catalysts as background to figure out the catalytic mechanism. 2.3 DFT computational details All calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program. The geometries of the reactants and intermediate products were optimized using B3LYP/6–31+G (d, p) method, vibration frequency calculations were made at the same computational level to verify the optimized structures to be ground states (zero imaginary frequency). Meanwhile, the calculated vibration frequencies of intermediate were corrected by the standard factor 0.96 to explore the reaction mechanism [27]. In addition, for the binding energy calculation, the single energy was calculated by using m062x/6–31+G (d, p) method after structure optimization. 2.4 Preparation of ILs Ionic liquids (Scheme 2 ) were all synthesized by acid-base neutralization at room temperature. In a typical process, [P4444]Br in ethanol passed through a strong base type anion exchange resin (Ambersep 900(OH)) packed column to obtain [P4444]OH solution. After being titrated by potassium biphthalate, the quantified [P4444]OH solution was mixed with equimolar acid and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. Subsequently, the mixture was rotary distilled to remove most of the ethanol and water, and the crude ionic liquid was vacuum-dried for at least 24 h at 50 °C. Notably, the proton ionic liquid [DBUH] [IsoNic] was synthesized by simply mixing equimolar superbase DBU and isonicotinic acid. As a result, all the products were viscous pale yellow liquids at temperature except [P4444] [IsoNic], which was a white powder. 2.5 General procedure for cycloaddition reaction All reactions were carried out in a 25 ml batch stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 2 ml of propylene oxide and an appropriate amount of ionic liquid were introduced into the reactor at room temperature, after CO2 at the designated pressure was charged, the autoclave was heated to the required temperature until the reaction was completed. Then, the remaining gas was released slowly after the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the ionic liquids Six non-halogen ionic liquids with [P4444], [P666614], [DBUH] and [BmmIm] as cation and [Nic], [IsoNic] and [2-Picolinic] as anion were synthesized by the above method. The prepared ILs were analyzed by taking advantage of NMR, HRMS, FTIR and the results suggested that all ionic liquids have been successfully synthesized (Fig S1–7). In addition, by further analyzing the FTIR of the ionic liquids with the same cation, It was found that the stretching vibrate of C = O and CO red shifted when the carboxylic group on anion moved from ortho-position to para-position, it was illustrated that the strength of bond was weekended, as a result, it was relatively easy for O− to interact with other substances. The thermogravimetric analysis of the prepared catalysts were performed to test their thermal stability. As demonstrated in Fig. 2, ionic liquids with [P66614]/ [P4444] as cation demonstrated above 300 °C, indicating their favorable thermal stability. [BmmIm] [IsoNic] showed moderate thermal stability, it decomposed at around 200 °C. Among all the ionic liquids, the protic ionic liquid [DBUH] [IsoNic] showed the worst stability, it could only remained stable blow 200 °C. Here, the basicity of the ionic liquids with different anions was tested by ultraviolet and PH tests (Fig 3). Fisrtly, for the ultraviolet test, when there was no added ionic liquid, the indicator (Bromothymol Blue) only showed acid peak in methanol, with the addition of ionic liquid, the active hydrogen of the indicator was captured by the basic ionic liquid, resulting in the basic indicator peak around 622 nm, the more basic the added ionic liquid was, the higher basic indicator peak showed. According to this raw, as Fig 3a showed, the basicity order was [P4444] [IsoNic] >[P4444] [Nic] >[P4444] [2-Picolinic]. As the Fig 3(b) showed, the PH data also confirmed the order. In order to reveal the interaction of the cation and anion, the Interaction Region Indicator (IRI) [28], which could show the chemical bonds and weak interactions in a chemical system and binding energy (EB) between cation and anion were calculated. In detail, for [DBUH] [IsoNic], there was a strong internal hydrogen bond between the [DBUH] and [IsoNic], and the EB was 95.17 kal/mol. For [BmmIm] [IsoNic] and [P4444] [IsoNic], there was green distribution between the cation and anion, indicating the weaker interaction compared with [DBUH] [IsoNic] [29], in addition, the EB was 92.13 and 90.02 kal/mol for [BmmIm] [IsoNic] and [P4444] [IsoNic], respectively. It could be concluded that the order of interaction of the cation and anion was [DBUH] [IsoNic] < [BmmIm] [IsoNic] < [P4444] [IsoNic]. 3.2 Performance of the prepared ionic liquids The catalytic activity of the prepared ionic liquids was evaluated by using propylene oxide as substrate. For the reaction without ionic liquid, there was almost no product. In a contrast, propylene carbonate can be efficiently obtained when ionic liquids were used as catalysts (Fig. 5). Firstly, for the ionic liquids with the different anion, the result showed that the activity order was [P4444] [IsoNic] (46.7 %) >[P4444] [Nic] (42.2 %) >[P4444] [2-Picolinic] (27.3 %), which was consistent with the order of their basictity (Fig 3) and reactivity of O− site(Fig 1 ). Then, for the ionic liquids with the different cation, the [BmmIm] [IsoNic] (36.2 %), showed a lower catalytic activity than [P4444] [IsoNic] (46.7 %), it could be explained by the interaction of the cation and anion, as the above analysis (Fig 4 ), for [BmmIm] [IsoNic], the cation and anion linked more closely than the [P4444] [IsoNic], which would limited the interaction of [IsoNic] and propylene oxide [30], then result in the reduced activity. For the [DBUH] [IsoNic], there was a strong internal hydrogen bonds between cation and anion, which would further inhibit the activity of anion (EB =95.17 kcal/mol), as a result, only 29.8 % of propylene carbonate was produced over 3 h at 100 °C. Finally, when the [P66614] was applied as cation, the yield decreased compared with [P4444], it could because the long flexible alkyl chain hindered [IsoNic] from contacting with the substrate [31]. Based on the above, [P4444] [IsoNic] was considered to be the better catalyst among the synthesized ionic liquids in this work. It could be concluded that anion affected the catalytic activity by affecting basictity of ionic liquids, the strong basicity was conducive to better catalytic activity, and the cation affected the catalytic activity by affecting activation ability of anion, the week interaction of cation and anion benefited the catalytic activity. 3.3 Substrate suitability of the optimized catalyst In order to examine the substrate suitability of [P4444] [IsoNic], diverse expoxide substrates were tested (Table 1 ) for the synthesis of corresponding cyclic carbonates at optimal condition (Fig S8). Generally, all tested epoxides were successfully converted to corresponding cyclic carbonates, which indicated that [P4444] [IsoNic] had general applicability to different epoxides. In detail, the substrates with alkyl chains displayed a high yield (Entry 1–2). In addition, due to the electron-absorbing group [32,33], epichlorohydrin had high reactivity, it could even be smoothly converted into cyclic carbonate at 80 °C with a yield of 96.9 % (Entry 3). However, when cyclohexane epoxide and styrene epoxide were used as substrates, steric hindrance of substrate prevented the nucleophilic attack of the catalyst, resulting in a decrease of yield(Entry 4–5). Finally, ether-bond functional substrates were also detected, and a moderate yield of matching products was obtained. (Entry 6). 3.4 Plausible catalytic mechanism According to previous reports, the opening of expoxide ring could be achieved in two ways: anion of ionic liquid directly nucleophilic attacking epoxides [34,35] and the anion coupling CO2 as a carboxylate to interact with epoxides [20]. In order to figure out the way that niacin-based non-halogen ionic liquids worked, a CO2 absorption experiment of [P4444] [Nic] was carried out. The infrared spectrum and NMR spectrum of [P4444] [Nic] before and after CO2 absorption were shown in Fig. 6 , as it showed, 1H NMR spectrum exhibited no obvious change of chemical shift while the 13CNMR spectrum manifested no obviously new carbon peak, there was also no obviously new stretching vibration peak of C = O between 1600 and 1800 cm−1 at the infrared spectrum. The NMR and infrared verified there was no chemically absorbed CO2 in ionic liquids together [25,36]. Hence, it was speculated that the ring-opening process was realized by an anion directly attacking propylene epoxide. To further prove the above speculation, [P4444] [IsoNic] catalyzed reaction was monitored by in-situ infrared [37], as Fig 7 a showed, firstly, only CO2 was injected into the system before 6 min, there was no signal within the range of 800–2000 cm−1. Subsequently, with the introduction of PO, signal peaks at 836, 949, 1015 and 1410 cm−1 appeared [38]. As time went on, one visible peak began to appear at 1800 cm−1 (Fig 7a and Fig 7b), the peak belonged to the stretching vibration peak of C = O in propylene carbonate [39], which indicated the reaction ran successfully. In addition, it could be found that except the peak at 1800 cm−1, there were also other new peaks appeared at 1616, 1683 and 1717 cm−1 (Fig 7a, Fig 7b and Fig. 7c) after the charge of PO. DFT calculations [37,38]were carried out to investigate whether they belonged to the frequency of reaction intermediate. The structure of the speculative intermediate formed by [IsoNic] anion directly attacking propylene epoxide (Fig. 7d) was optimized and the frequency of its bonds were calculated [40], the result showed that the stretching vibration peak of C = O in it was at 1682 cm−1. It was reasonably speculated that the new peak at 1683 cm−1 (Fig. 7c) was belonged to the speculative ring-opening intermediate, which provided a compelling evidence for the view that ring-opening process was realized by anion directly attacking propylene epoxide. Further, the structure of another speculative intermediate formed by the speculative ring-opening intermediate coupling a CO2 (Fig. 7e) was optimized and the frequency of its bonds was also calculated, the result showed that the two stretching vibration peaks of C = O in it were at 1624 and 1699 cm−1, corresponding to the peaks at 1616 and 1717 cm−1 on the in-situ infrared spectrum [37,38], respectively. Based on the above experiments, a possible mechanism for [P4444] [IsoNic] catalyzed cycloaddition reaction was proposed and shown in Scheme 3 . Firstly, the [P4444] interacts with oxygen atoms to polarize the CO bond of the epoxide [25]. Meanwhile, the [IsoNic] directly attacked the less sterically hindered carbon atom of the epoxide to generate the ring-opened intermediate Int 1. Subsequently, the formed intermediate spontaneously interacts with CO2 molecule to realize the CO2 insertion. Following an intramolecular cyclization step, the product is produced and the catalyst is regenerated. 4 Conclusion In summary, six carboxylic acid ionic liquids with different spacial structures of cations and anions are successfully synthesized and used for catalyzing cycloaddition reaction. It is found that both cation and anion have key effect on catalytic activity of non-halogen ionic liquids. In detail, the anion could improve the catalytic activity by improve the basicity of ionic liquids, and the cation that has a weak interaction with anion is more conducive for the reactivity, because it is beneficial for anion to interact with propylene oxide. The optimized [P4444] [IsoNic] could achieve 92.1 % yield of propylene carbonate and it also has general applicability to diverse epoxides. Finally, two reaction intermediates are captured by In-situ infrared, combined with DFT calculation, the anion-induced ring-opening mechanism is proposed. This work provides an in-depth understanding of the catalytic contribution of anion and cation of non-halogen ionic liquids in catalyzing cycloaddition reaction. coredata.dc:description: Non-halogen ionic liquids are considered efficient catalyst for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates. In this work, six carboxylic acid ionic liquids with different types and sizes of cations are designed and synthesized to systematically investigate the catalytic contribution of the non-halogen cation and anion for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonate. The result shows that the anion could improve the catalytic activity by improve the basicity of ionic liquids, and the cation that has a weak interaction with anion is more conducive for the reactivity. Further, the reaction mechanism is deeply studied by using the optimized [P4444][IsoNic]: two reaction intermediates are captured by In-situ infrared, combined with DFT calculation, the anion directly inducing ring-opening mechanism is proposed. This work provides an in-depth understanding of catalytic contribution of non-halogen ionic liquids used in cycloaddition reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into catalytic contribution of non-halogen cation and anion for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonate
